item.content:encoded:
The NATO SHAPE Internship Programme 2027 is now open — offering a paid international internship opportunity for students and recent graduates who want to gain professional experience inside one of the world’s leading international organizations.

Based at the Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe (SHAPE) in Mons, Belgium, the programme provides hands-on exposure to international cooperation, policy, communications, technology, and operational support while receiving a monthly stipend.

Application deadline: 28 February 2026
Applications submitted after the deadline will not be considered.

What Is the NATO SHAPE Internship Programme?

The SHAPE Internship Programme (SIP) is designed to give young professionals practical work experience within NATO while supporting the organization with fresh academic knowledge and technical skills.

Each year, approximately 35 interns are selected from NATO member countries to work across different divisions and offices. The programme aims to:

  • Provide real-world experience in an international environment

  • Strengthen understanding of NATO and its operations

  • Promote diversity across member nations

  • Support SHAPE divisions with additional expertise

Interns gain valuable professional experience while building strong international career credentials.

Internship Location and Duration

  • Location: SHAPE Headquarters, Mons, Belgium

  • Duration: 6 months

  • Start Dates: January or September (following year)

  • Application Cycle: One annual call for applications

Applicants must specify their preferred start month during the application process.

Areas of Interest and Academic Backgrounds

SHAPE accepts candidates from a broad range of disciplines, including:

Policy and International Affairs

  • International Relations

  • Political Science

  • Defence and Security Studies

  • Law

Business and Administration

  • Economics and Finance

  • Accounting and Auditing

  • Human Resources

  • Logistics

Technology and Engineering

  • Information Technology

  • Cybersecurity

  • Engineering

  • Electronics

  • Aeronautics

Communications and Media

  • Media and Journalism

  • Strategic Communications

  • Digital Media

  • Web and Graphic Design

  • Public Relations

Additional Specializations

  • Intelligence and Security

  • Library Sciences

  • Languages (Russian, Ukrainian, Arabic)

Featured Opportunity: Strategic Communications Internship

For the 2027 cycle, SHAPE is particularly seeking candidates who can support strategic communications and employer branding activities. Responsibilities may include:

  • Supporting digital outreach and social media activities

  • Contributing to employer branding initiatives

  • Assisting with podcast development and multimedia projects

  • Expanding presence on emerging social platforms

  • Supporting communication campaigns

This area is well suited to candidates in communications, marketing, digital media, human resources, or related fields.

Eligibility Criteria

To qualify for the NATO SHAPE Internship Programme, applicants must:

  • Be citizens of a NATO member nation

  • Be at least 21 years old at the time of application

  • Demonstrate strong English proficiency (primary working language)

  • Have completed a first university degree

  • Be current MA/MSc or PhD students, or recent graduates (within the last 18 months)

Normally, candidates should not be over 35 years old unless engaged in a PhD programme relevant to SHAPE.

Only applications meeting all eligibility criteria will be considered.

Is the NATO SHAPE Internship Paid?

Yes. The internship includes financial support.

Internship benefits include:

  • Monthly lump sum: €1,286.09

  • Travel reimbursement for arrival and departure (according to regulations)

  • Professional experience in a multinational international environment

Interns are responsible for:

  • Arranging their accommodation

  • Securing health and accident insurance

  • Completing administrative formalities required by Belgian authorities

Typical Responsibilities of Interns

Depending on the assigned division, interns may:

  • Draft and prepare official documents

  • Conduct research and analysis

  • Attend and summarize meetings and conferences

  • Support media analysis and public relations activities

  • Assist technical or administrative teams

  • Contribute to communication and digital projects

Application Process

Applications must be submitted electronically through the official application form.

Required Documents

Applicants must upload one combined file (PDF or Word) containing:

  • Curriculum Vitae (CV)

  • One-page motivation essay explaining interest in SHAPE and expectations from the internship

File naming example: JohnBrown.pdf

Incomplete or incorrectly submitted applications will be automatically rejected.

If you identify an error after submission, you may resubmit your application. The latest version will be considered.

Selection Process

The selection process includes:

  1. Initial screening by SHAPE Civilian Human Resources Management Branch

  2. Review by relevant divisions and offices

  3. Selection based on skills and organizational needs

  4. Final decisions typically made between May and June

Only selected candidates will be notified.

Security Clearance Requirement

Depending on the assigned role, selected interns may need security clearance from their national authorities. Processing times vary and may take several weeks to several months.

Key Deadline

Application Deadline: 28 February 2026

Applications received after this date will not be considered for the 2027 internship cycle.

Contact Information

For further information:

SHAPE Internship Programme Coordinator
Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe (SHAPE)
Email: SHAPEinternship@shape.nato.int

Why Apply for the NATO SHAPE Internship?

The SHAPE Internship Programme provides paid international experience in a highly respected global institution. Interns gain practical skills, professional exposure, and insight into multinational cooperation, making it an excellent opportunity for those interested in careers in international organizations, communications, policy, technology, or global affairs.

While internships are not directly linked to recruitment, the experience significantly strengthens future career prospects.

Application Process

Applications must be submitted electronically through the official application form.

FOR MORE DETAILS

item.content:encoded:
The LAC AI Accelerator 2026 is now open for applications, inviting multidisciplinary teams across Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) to pilot high-impact artificial intelligence (AI) solutions for public sector transformation. Led by the World Bank, this initiative aims to help governments test, validate, and scale AI use cases that strengthen digital governance and public service delivery.

If your team is developing AI tools for government modernization, policy innovation, or operational efficiency in the region, this accelerator provides strategic support and global visibility.

About the LAC AI Accelerator

The LAC AI Accelerator supports collaborative teams composed of members from:

  • Public institutions

  • Private sector organizations

  • Academic institutions

  • Civil society groups

The program focuses on AI solutions that deliver measurable improvements in public administration and governance across Latin America and the Caribbean.

Rather than scaling untested ideas, the accelerator emphasizes piloting, validation, and institutional readiness before broader implementation.

Focus Areas

Selected AI use cases should aim to improve:

  • Digital government services

  • Public sector efficiency

  • Policy design and delivery systems

The accelerator encourages practical, implementable solutions that address real governance challenges in the region.

What Selected Teams Receive

Participating teams benefit from:

  • AI readiness and institutional maturity assessment

  • Strategic and technical mentorship

  • Specialized AI training with a certificate from the World Bank Group

  • Visibility at the World Bank Digital Summit

These benefits help teams refine their solutions while strengthening institutional capacity for responsible AI deployment.

Program Requirements

Teams must meet the following conditions:

  • Secure a commitment letter from a public digital authority

  • Provide their own technological infrastructure

  • Submit a detailed AI use case proposal

  • Complete a privacy consent form

The institutional commitment letter is a mandatory requirement, ensuring alignment with public sector priorities.

Application Deadline

Applications are open through March 16, 2026.

Interested teams are encouraged to begin securing institutional commitments early to meet submission requirements.

Carefully review all eligibility and documentation requirements before applying.

                                  How to Apply

Learn more and submit your application here.

For more OFY Accelerator opportunities, visit here

item.content:encoded:
The United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) has officially opened applications for the 2026 Young Champions of the Earth award, a flagship global initiative that supports young innovators developing solutions to climate change, biodiversity loss, pollution, and environmental degradation. The programme provides funding, mentorship, training, and international exposure to young people with proven environmental ideas that can create measurable impact.

Applications are open from 24 February to 31 March 2026, and selected winners will receive financial support and opportunities to engage with global environmental leaders and decision-makers.

What Is the UNEP Young Champions of the Earth Award?

The Young Champions of the Earth award is UNEP’s leading youth engagement initiative aimed at identifying and supporting ambitious young people who are creating innovative solutions to protect and restore the environment. Since its launch in 2017, the programme has recognized 33 young environmental leaders aged 18 to 30, including activists, entrepreneurs, scientists, and innovators.

The initiative is implemented in partnership with cleantech entrepreneur Chris Kemper, UNEP Advocate for Partnerships and co-founder of Planet A. The programme focuses on empowering young leaders whose ideas contribute to environmental sustainability while also demonstrating social and economic value.

What Winners Receive

Selected Young Champions receive a comprehensive support package designed to help them scale their ideas and expand their impact globally. Benefits include:

  • US$10,000 seed funding to implement their environmental project

  • Mentorship and training from environmental experts and industry leaders

  • Access to a global network of innovators and change-makers

  • Opportunities to participate in high-level United Nations events

  • International media exposure and global recognition

  • Participation in a pitch competition in New York hosted by Planet A

  • Opportunity to win an additional grant of up to US$100,000

Winners are also expected to document their journey through self-produced videos and short articles, supported by a multimedia production kit and communications training provided by UNEP.

Who Should Apply?

UNEP encourages applications from young people across diverse sectors and backgrounds who are advancing innovative ideas for people, planet, and prosperity. Applicants may come from areas such as:

  • Entrepreneurship and startups

  • Science and research

  • Economics and finance

  • Arts and storytelling

  • Education and communication

  • Technology and innovation

  • Community activism and advocacy

Applicants must demonstrate that they have actively worked on their idea for at least six months prior to applying.

Eligibility Criteria

To be eligible for the Young Champions of the Earth 2026 award, applicants must:

  • Be between 18 and 30 years old by the end of the calendar year

  • Have at least six months of experience implementing their environmental idea

  • Submit only one application per year

  • Apply as an individual rather than a group

Previous applicants are allowed to apply again, provided they submit a new application.

Employees of UNEP, Planet A, CoalitionWild, and their immediate family members are not eligible to participate.

Apply to become a 2026 Young Champion of the Earth.

What UNEP Is Looking For

Applications are evaluated by United Nations experts based on several core criteria designed to identify ideas with strong potential for environmental and social impact.

The 3 Ps Framework

  • Planet: Positive environmental impact

  • People: Social benefits and community relevance

  • Prosperity: Financial viability and long-term sustainability

The 3 Cs Framework

  • Curiosity

  • Courage

  • Creativity

Additional Selection Factors

  • Demonstrated commitment through at least six months of implementation

  • Bankability, meaning the idea shows potential for investment or scale

  • Strong endorsement from a referee who can validate the applicant’s work

Examples of Past Winning Innovations

Recent winners demonstrate the diversity and creativity of ideas supported through the programme. Examples include:

  • Plant-based leather alternatives created from banana crop waste

  • Biodegradable packaging produced from invasive water hyacinth pulp

  • Systems that convert greywater into safe drinking water

These examples highlight that successful ideas can emerge from technology, agriculture, circular economy solutions, education, or community-based environmental initiatives.

Why This Opportunity Matters

Global environmental challenges such as climate change, biodiversity loss, land degradation, and pollution require innovative solutions driven by new generations of leaders. UNEP emphasizes that addressing these challenges can also generate economic and social benefits.

According to UNEP Executive Director Inger Andersen, investing in young innovators helps transform ambitious ideas into viable solutions that benefit communities while protecting the planet.

Key Application Details

  • Programme: UNEP Young Champions of the Earth 2026

  • Application period: 24 February to 31 March 2026

  • Seed funding: US$10,000 per winner

  • Additional funding opportunity: Up to US$100,000 via Planet A pitch competition

  • Travel: Fully funded for official programme events

  • Global competition open to young people worldwide

Frequently Asked Questions

Do applicants need to study environmental science?
No. Applicants from any background are encouraged to apply as long as their idea addresses environmental challenges.

Is there an application fee?
No. Applying is free.

Can teams apply?
No. The award recognizes individuals, although projects may involve teams.

What happens if selected?
Winners receive funding, mentorship, training, international visibility, and opportunities to pitch for additional funding.

Are there restrictions on how the prize money is used?
Yes. The initial US$10,000 must be used to implement the winning idea, and winners must submit a final report and budget.

Travel and Participation Requirements

Selected Young Champions will be required to travel to attend award ceremonies, workshops, and the Planet A pitch competition in New York. All travel expenses are covered, but winners must hold valid passports.

Winners must also:

  • Share their personal stories through videos and media features

  • Participate in mentorship and storytelling activities

  • Allow UNEP to use their stories for promotional purposes across various platforms

Join the UNEP Youth Network

All applicants become part of UNEP’s global youth community, which connects environmental activists and innovators worldwide and provides updates on new opportunities and initiatives.

Final Thoughts

The UNEP Young Champions of the Earth 2026 award is one of the most prestigious global opportunities for young environmental leaders. It offers more than funding — it provides mentorship, international exposure, and a platform to scale innovative solutions that address some of the world’s most urgent environmental challenges.

If you are a young changemaker working on a bold idea that can improve environmental outcomes and create real impact, this programme offers a powerful pathway to accelerate your work on a global stage.

Are you ready to take action? 

Apply to become a 2026 Young Champion of the Earth.

Applications are open until 31 March 2026. Young innovators ready to transform their environmental ideas into scalable solutions are encouraged to apply through the official Young Champions of the Earth application platform.

Further Resources

  • Contest rules
  • What we’re looking for
  • Join the Network
  • FAQs
  • Learn more here.

item.content:encoded:
The FAO Young Forest Champions Programme 2026 is a targeted youth leadership initiative supporting young people who are actively advancing forest action in Ghana, Indonesia, Kenya, Peru, Uganda, and Zambia. Led by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) under the AIM4Forests initiative, the programme aims to strengthen youth-led solutions for forest protection, restoration, and sustainable forest management.

The programme recognizes that young people in forest-rich countries are already driving change on the ground. By offering visibility, leadership development, and opportunities to engage with global forest processes, the initiative helps elevate local action to regional and international platforms.

About the FAO Young Forest Champions Programme

The Young Forest Champions Programme is designed to showcase and support youth-led initiatives that contribute to sustainable forest management and climate resilience in the six participating countries. Through the programme, FAO connects young leaders to global discussions on forests, biodiversity, and climate, while ensuring that local experiences and perspectives inform international policy conversations.

Selected participants become part of a cohort of Young Forest Champions whose work highlights innovative and community-driven approaches to forest stewardship.

Why This Opportunity Matters

Forests are essential for climate mitigation, biodiversity conservation, and the livelihoods of millions of people. Countries such as Ghana, Indonesia, Kenya, Peru, Uganda, and Zambia are home to critical forest ecosystems that face increasing pressure from deforestation, land degradation, and climate impacts.

By investing in youth leadership in these contexts, the FAO Young Forest Champions Programme supports locally grounded solutions and strengthens youth participation in forest governance. The programme ensures that young people working directly with forest communities have a voice in shaping broader strategies and policies related to sustainable forest management.

Who Can Apply

The programme is open to:

  • Young people typically between 18 and 35 years old.
  • Applicants based in Ghana, Indonesia, Kenya, Peru, Uganda, or Zambia.
  • Individuals or representatives of youth-led initiatives focused on forest-related action.
  • Candidates who can demonstrate leadership, innovation, and measurable impact in their work.

Eligible initiatives may include forest conservation, restoration, sustainable forest use, agroforestry, community forestry, forest-based livelihoods, Indigenous and traditional knowledge, research, advocacy, or awareness-raising activities aligned with forest sustainability goals.

What the Programme Offers

Young Forest Champions receive non-financial support designed to increase visibility and influence, including:

  • Global recognition through FAO platforms and communication channels.
  • Expert mentorship and structured technical training
  • Hands-on experience in forest restoration and ecosystem monitoring
  • Exposure to advanced tools such as remote sensing and digital monitoring technologies 
  • Participation in a network of youth forest leaders

The programme does not provide direct funding but instead focuses on strengthening leadership, networks, and strategic positioning for long-term impact.

Role and Expectations of Young Forest Champions

Selected champions are expected to:

  • Share experiences and lessons learned from their forest-related initiatives.
  • Contribute youth perspectives to FAO-led dialogues and campaigns.
  • Inspire peer engagement in forest action at local and national levels.
  • Support knowledge exchange across countries and forest contexts.

Selection Process

Applications are reviewed by FAO based on:

  • Alignment with forest sustainability and AIM4Forests objectives.
  • Demonstrated leadership and commitment to youth engagement.
  • Evidence of impact and potential for broader influence.

Shortlisted candidates may be contacted for additional information during the review process.

Deadline

📅 Application deadline: 21 March 2026

Applicants are encouraged to apply early and clearly demonstrate how their work contributes to sustainable forest management in their country.

Learn more and apply here.

item.content:encoded:
Looking for an international study abroad experience that combines rigorous academics with real-world learning? The School for International Training (SIT Study Abroad) offers semester, summer, and academic-year programs across Africa, Asia, Latin America, Europe, and the Middle East. For 2027, SIT programs provide immersive, field-based learning that allows students to explore critical global issues while earning academic credit.

SIT programs are designed for students seeking transformative educational experiences that go beyond traditional classroom learning. Participants engage in experiential learning, combining coursework with practical fieldwork, community engagement, and independent research projects.

Why Choose SIT 

SIT Study Abroad is ideal for students who want more than a traditional classroom experience. Programs emphasize intercultural competence, field-based learning, and real-world problem solving, providing skills and experiences that prepare students for careers in international development, environmental science, public health, education, and beyond.

By combining immersive cultural experiences, academic rigor, and independent research, SIT enables students to develop a global perspective, build professional networks, and gain practical experience that sets them apart in both academic and professional environments.

Who Can Apply

SIT programs are open to:

  • Undergraduate students enrolled at accredited colleges or universities.

  • Students in good academic standing who meet program-specific prerequisites.

  • Applicants interested in global issues such as sustainability, climate change, human rights, public health, development, and cultural studies.

Each program may have additional requirements, such as language proficiency or specific prior coursework. Students are encouraged to consult the SIT website for detailed program requirements before applying.

Program Structure

SIT Study Abroad programs blend academic instruction with hands-on learning, offering:

  • Thematic courses focused on global challenges such as environmental sustainability, social inequality, migration, and health.
  • Field-based learning, including site visits, community engagement, and applied research projects.
  • Independent Study Projects (ISPs) that allow students to explore a topic of personal interest in depth, often involving field research or collaboration with local partners.
  • Opportunities for cultural immersion, including homestays, local mentorship, and language learning.

Semester programs typically run for 12–15 weeks, while academic-year programs can extend up to 30 weeks. Summer programs are shorter, offering 6–7 week immersive experiences with intensive learning and fieldwork.

Academic Credit and Support

Students earn fully transferable academic credit through SIT’s accredited U.S. institution. Academic advising, on-site staff support, and risk management systems ensure that participants have a safe and academically productive experience. SIT also provides guidance on visa applications, health and safety, and travel arrangements.

Financial aid and scholarships may be available for eligible students, depending on program and funding cycles. Prospective participants are encouraged to review the website and consult their home institution’s study abroad office early in the planning process.

Fields of Study

SIT programs cover a wide range of thematic areas:

  • Climate and Environment: Programs exploring sustainability, conservation, and climate action in local contexts.
  • Development and Inequality: Addressing social, economic, and political dimensions of development and social justice.
  • Global Health: Studying public health challenges and community-based health initiatives in diverse regions.
  • Peace, Conflict, and Human Rights: Engaging with issues of governance, migration, and human rights protection.
  • Education and Cultural Studies: Examining learning systems, cultural preservation, and cross-cultural engagement.

Each program is grounded in local context, providing students with real-world exposure to regional challenges and opportunities.

Application and Deadlines

SIT operates on a rolling admissions basis, which means program availability and deadlines vary by location, academic term, and field of study. Popular programs, including Spring 2027, fill quickly, so early application is strongly recommended.

Applicants should:

  • Review program prerequisites carefully.
  • Coordinate with their home institution regarding credit transfer.
  • Prepare academic transcripts, essays, and recommendation letters in advance.

Completing applications early increases the likelihood of placement in preferred programs and access to financial aid.

Explore programs and more details here.

Looking for more opportunities? Check out the Opportunities for Youth website!

item.content:encoded:
The Global Africa Translation Fellowship 2026, hosted by The Africa Institute at Global Studies University in Sharjah, UAE, is now open for applications. This non-residential fellowship provides funding of up to $5,000 to support the translation of significant works from the African continent and its diaspora into English or Arabic, with other target languages also considered.

As part of The Africa Institute’s African Languages and Translation Program, this initiative seeks to broaden global access to essential texts in African and African Diaspora studies, including literary, theoretical, and critical works that have shaped intellectual traditions across the Global South.

About The Africa Institute

The Africa Institute is a research and academic institution dedicated to the interdisciplinary study of Africa and its global connections. Based in Sharjah, United Arab Emirates, the Institute fosters scholarship, translation, publication, and dialogue that expands global understanding of African intellectual and cultural production.

The Global Africa Translation Fellowship reflects the Institute’s commitment to linguistic accessibility, knowledge circulation, and scholarly exchange across regions.

Fellowship Overview

The Global Africa Translation Fellowship is designed to:

  • Make foundational African and African Diaspora texts accessible to wider global audiences

  • Support translators working across the Global South

  • Encourage retranslations of classic works

  • Fund previously untranslated texts

  • Promote poetry, prose, and critical theory translations

The fellowship is non-residential, meaning fellows complete their translation projects remotely and are not required to relocate to the UAE.

Funding ranges from $1,000 to $5,000, depending on:

  • Project scope

  • Complexity

  • Quality of proposal

  • Feasibility within the fellowship timeframe

Why This Fellowship Matters

Translation plays a vital role in:

  • Knowledge democratization

  • Decolonizing academic discourse

  • Amplifying African voices

  • Strengthening Global South intellectual exchange

By funding translation projects, the fellowship enables African scholarship and literature to reach broader audiences and reshape global conversations.

What Types of Projects Are Eligible?

Eligible translation projects include:

  • Previously untranslated African literary or theoretical works

  • Retranslations of classic texts

  • Poetry collections

  • Prose works

  • Critical theory texts

  • Works-in-progress

  • Newly conceived projects that can be completed within the fellowship period

The fellowship is flexible in allowing projects that are either underway or newly initiated, provided they are feasible within the grant timeframe.

Funding Structure

Grant Amount: $1,000–$5,000

Disbursement:

  • First installment at project commencement

  • Second installment upon successful completion

Recipients must submit a copy of the completed translation for archival purposes. The Institute will not publish or use the translation without the awardee’s consent.

Who Can Apply?

The fellowship is open to applicants from across the Global South.

Applicants must demonstrate:

  • Strong translation capacity

  • Academic or professional expertise

  • Ability to complete the proposed work

Selection is based on:

  • Quality of proposal

  • Significance of text

  • Feasibility

  • Demonstrated scholarly or translation experience

Application Requirements

Applicants must submit the following:

  1. Two-page CV/Resume

    • Institutional affiliation

    • Highest degree obtained

    • Key publications or translation works

  2. Two-page Project Summary (single-spaced, font 12)

    • Description of translation

    • Significance of the work

    • Justification for re-translation (if applicable)

    • Proposed completion dates

  3. 4–5-page Sample (double-spaced, font 12)

    • Original text excerpt

    • Corresponding translation

  4. Copyright Documentation

    • If not in the public domain

    • Copy of copyright notice

    • Letter from copyright holder confirming English-language rights availability

Attachments must not exceed 3 MB each.

Applications must be submitted through the online platform. Email submissions are not accepted.

Selection Process

Applications are reviewed by:

  • Faculty members

  • Research fellows at The Africa Institute

Selection criteria include:

  • Scholarly rigor

  • Translation quality

  • Cultural significance

  • Clarity of proposal

  • Feasibility

Application Deadline

Thursday, March 12, 2026.

Late submissions will not be considered.

APPLY HERE

Contact Information

For inquiries: applications@theafricainstitute.org

Click here for more information about the Global Africa Translation Fellowship programme 2026.

Discover more fellowship opportunities here.

item.content:encoded:
Are you an ambitious student or recent graduate passionate about international affairs, geopolitics, public policy, and strategic communications? Here’s your chance to join one of Europe’s leading geopolitical advisory firms, Rasmussen Global, as a Junior Advisor Intern for the 2026 Fall Internship Program — a career-defining opportunity to work at the nexus of policy, politics, and business.

What Is the Rasmussen Global Internship?

Rasmussen Global’s 2026 Junior Advisor Internship offers hands-on, professional experience working closely with expert advisers across global capitals, including Copenhagen, Brussels, and beyond. Interns support client work involving international politics, global security, open market advocacy, and strategic policy initiatives — all while gaining unmatched exposure to decision-makers and leading industry experts.

This internship is ideal for individuals who want to:

  • Build expertise in international relations and geopolitics

  • Gain real-world consulting and advisory experience

  • Work in a dynamic, multicultural professional environment

  • Contribute to shaping narratives on democracy, security, and global policy

What You’ll Do: Junior Advisor Responsibilities

As a Junior Advisor Intern, you will be expected to:

  • Assist with research and policy analysis on geopolitical topics

  • Draft clear written reports, briefings, and client documents

  • Support senior advisors during strategic planning and outreach

  • Engage with political, business, and media stakeholders

  • Contribute to real, client-facing work that informs decision-making

This internship is both challenging and rewarding, requiring initiative, responsiveness, and professionalism.

Top Benefits of the Internship

While specific benefits are usually shared once offers are made, interns historically enjoy:

  • Build a global professional network

  • Cross-cultural teamwork and global policy engagement

3. Career Advantages

Where This Opportunity Is Based

Primary Location: Copenhagen, Denmark
Secondary collaboration may involve offices and partners in Brussels, Berlin, Madrid, Kyiv, and other global hubs.

Who Should Apply? Qualifications & Eligibility

This internship is competitive and structured for proactive learners who bring both academic foundation and drive.

Ideal Candidate Profile:

1. Current bachelor’s or master’s student (final year preferred)
2. Studying Political Science, International Relations, Economics, Public Policy, Security Studies, or related fields
3. Strong analytical and communication skills (written + spoken)
4. Proactive, reliable, and capable of working with teams across time zones
5. Interest in geopolitics, international affairs, and cross-sector strategy

While Rasmussen Global does not publicly list strict academic thresholds, relevant coursework and demonstrable leadership will make applicants stand out.

How to Apply — Official Links & Steps

To apply for this prestigious program, follow these steps:

Tip: Early applications are hugely advantageous — firms with rolling deadlines may close positions once they are filled.

Insider Tips — Boost Your Odds of Winning an Internship

•  Emphasize global experience, research, language skills, and international perspectives

The Rasmussen Global Junior Advisor Internship — 2026 Cohort is a high-impact international opportunity for students and future leaders seeking to launch careers in global affairs consultancy and strategic policy work. item.content:encoded:
The Private Equity Stakeholder Project (PESP) has opened applications for a Climate Director (Remote) — a rare senior-level opportunity for experienced climate, environmental justice, and corporate accountability professionals to directly challenge private equity’s role in the climate crisis.

This is a fully remote, full-time leadership position with a competitive salary, strong benefits, and national-level influence across climate advocacy, sustainable finance, and environmental justice movements.

If you have deep experience in climate campaigns, financial research, and leading advocacy teams, this role puts you at the center of high-stakes climate accountability work.

About the Private Equity Stakeholder Project (PESP)

PESP is a nonprofit financial watchdog organization that investigates how private equity firms impact communities, workers, and the environment. The organization focuses on increasing transparency in a sector that often operates behind closed doors — especially when it comes to fossil fuel investments, energy infrastructure, and environmental harm.

Through rigorous research, data-driven reporting, and coalition-based campaigns, PESP partners with:

  • Frontline and environmental justice communities

  • Institutional investors

  • Policymakers and regulators

  • Labor unions and advocacy organizations

Their work plays a growing role in shaping climate accountability within global finance.

Role Overview: Climate Director (Remote)

The Climate Director will lead PESP’s Climate Team and oversee all research, strategy, and campaign efforts focused on private equity’s climate impact.

This role blends:

  • Strategic research leadership

  • Corporate accountability campaigning

  • Team management

  • Coalition and investor engagement

  • Environmental justice advocacy

You’ll report directly to the Executive Director and help shape national-level climate accountability strategies.

Why This Role Matters

Private equity is reshaping the global energy system — often quietly, and often in ways that accelerate climate harm.

As Climate Director, you will:

  • Confront opaque financial power structures

  • Support communities on the frontlines of fossil fuel investment

  • Influence investor behavior and policy discussions

  • Help align financial systems with climate and justice goals

This is not just a job — it’s a platform for high-impact climate leadership at a moment when accountability in finance has never mattered more.

Strategic Purpose of the Role

Private equity firms control vast portfolios in:

  • Fossil fuel extraction

  • Power generation

  • Energy infrastructure

  • Carbon-intensive industries

Yet they often face limited public oversight.

The Climate Director’s mission is to close this accountability gap by:

  • Exposing harmful investment practices

  • Building powerful coalitions

  • Pressuring asset managers toward climate-aligned behavior

  • Supporting frontline communities affected by fossil fuel investments

Core Responsibilities

1. Climate Accountability & Environmental Justice Leadership

  • Lead PESP’s corporate accountability work in the energy and fossil fuel sectors

  • Identify pathways for systemic reform in private equity investment practices

  • Center environmental justice and frontline community voices

2. Team Leadership & Management

  • Supervise and mentor multiple research and campaign staff

  • Strengthen internal research, advocacy, and data capacity

  • Support professional growth and skill development

3. Research Oversight & Data Strategy

You will oversee sophisticated research initiatives, including:

  • Managing multi-staff research workflows

  • Developing and maintaining datasets on private equity energy investments

  • Analyzing environmental and climate impact data

  • Producing high-impact public reports for investors, policymakers, and advocates

  • Collaborating across organizations on shared data systems

4. Campaign Strategy & Public Engagement

  • Design and execute strategic campaigns targeting private asset managers

  • Set campaign priorities and action plans

  • Coordinate with communications and design teams

  • Edit reports for legal accuracy and strategic clarity

  • Engage with media, policymakers, investors, unions, and grassroots groups

5. Coalition & Relationship Building

  • Build partnerships with:

    • Environmental justice organizations

    • Frontline community groups

    • ESG-focused institutional investors

    • Climate and accountability coalitions

  • Translate complex financial research into compelling, accessible narratives

6. Travel & Organizational Reporting

  • Report directly to the Executive Director

  • Participate in occasional travel for coalition meetings, campaigns, and stakeholder engagement

Required Experience & Qualifications

PESP is seeking senior-level candidates with:

1. Professional Experience

  • 10+ years in strategic research and/or advocacy campaigning

  • Proven leadership experience managing teams

  • Demonstrated success in environmental justice or climate campaigns

  • Experience developing and executing campaign strategies

2. Technical & Data Skills

Hands-on experience with:

  • Large datasets and data analysis

  • Airtable or SQL (data management)

  • R or Python (analysis)

  • Data visualization tools

3. Communication & Advocacy

  • Exceptional written and verbal communication skills

  • Experience engaging:

    • Investors

    • Policymakers

    • Media

    • Labor unions

    • Community-based organizations

4. Values & Commitment

  • Strong understanding of financial advocacy within climate movements

  • Deep commitment to social, economic, and climate justice

  • Applications strongly encouraged from women, BIPOC, and LGBTQ+ candidates

Salary, Compensation & Benefits

Salary Range:
$105,000 – $120,000 USD, based on experience

 Benefits Include:

  • Medical, dental, and vision insurance

  • 401(k) retirement savings plan

  • Comprehensive employee benefits package

  • Fully remote work structure

This compensation reflects the seniority, leadership responsibility, and national impact of the role.

How to Apply:

Applicants must complete a detailed online application form, including written responses addressing:

  • Motivation for applying

  • Commitment to social, economic, and climate justice

  • Experience in environmental justice campaigns

  • Experience analyzing environmental impact data

  • Leadership and team management experience

Apply here

IMPORTANT:
Do NOT use artificial intelligence when writing your application responses or submitting writing samples. PESP explicitly evaluates authentic writing and communication skills.

Application Deadline: 6th March 2026

For more information visit here

For more global opportunties click here

item.content:encoded:
The Nelson Mandela Foundation is inviting applications for an International Relations Consultant to support its global justice programme. This is a 12-month independent contract that can be structured as either part-time or full-time, depending on the availability of the successful candidate.

This role offers a unique opportunity to contribute to impactful work advancing peace, human rights, and democracy across Africa and globally, in line with the legacy of Nelson Mandela.

About the Role

The consultant will support the Foundation’s regional justice project, helping drive research, advocacy, and stakeholder coordination efforts that address contemporary political challenges across the African continent.

The role is ideal for a professional with strong grounding in political theory, African regional dynamics, and international relations, combined with the ability to engage with evolving political narratives and global power structures.

Background & Programme Focus

Global justice is a strategic priority for the Foundation. Its work seeks to:

  • Promote awareness and action on peace, human rights, and democracy

  • Address interconnected global and African conflicts

  • Challenge structural inequalities and global power imbalances

  • Foster equitable and democratic societies across the continent

Through research, convening, and coalition-building, the Foundation aims to strengthen leadership, public awareness, and policy engagement on pressing African justice issues.

Key Responsibilities

The International Relations Consultant will:

  • Support the Head of Department in implementing the regional justice project

  • Conduct policy research and analysis on African and global justice issues

  • Lead stakeholder engagement and convening

  • Contribute to organisational knowledge and strategic insights

  • Provide ad-hoc international relations research support across programmes

Qualifications & Experience

To be considered, candidates should have:

  • A Bachelor’s or postgraduate degree in International Relations or a related field

  • 3–5 years of relevant professional experience

  • Demonstrated experience working on African regional issues

  • Strong skills in research, writing, networking, and coordination

  • Proficiency in Microsoft Office and digital collaboration tools

Contract Details

  • Contract Type: Independent consultant

  • Duration: 12 months

  • Work Arrangement: Part-time or full-time (depending on availability)

  • Location: Flexible (with coordination across Foundation programmes)

Why This Opportunity Matters

This role is more than a consultancy—it is a chance to shape conversations and action on justice in Africa and beyond. You will contribute to meaningful work that advances equity, strengthens democratic values, and challenges systems of oppression.

Key Skills and Expertise

The Foundation is seeking candidates with strong analytical and communication capabilities, including:

  • Excellent research and writing skills

  • Sound understanding of international relations, including:

    • Peace and justice

    • International governance and cooperation

    • Political economy

  • Ability to work independently and manage outputs

  • Strong stakeholder engagement and relationship management skills

  • Effective written, verbal, and listening communication abilities

Required Attributes and Competencies

Successful applicants will demonstrate:

  • A proactive mindset and initiative

  • A structured and organised approach to delivering outputs

  • A solution-oriented work ethic

  • The ability to engage effectively with diverse stakeholders

Application Process

Please send the following documentation and information to recruitment@nelsonmandela.org

Required Application Materials

  • Updated CV with two contactable references

  • Availability details (part-time or full-time; if part-time, specify days available per week)

  • Salary expectations (for part-time or full-time)

  • Earliest available start date

Application Deadline

6 March 2026

Applications received after the deadline may not be considered, so early submission is strongly encouraged.

For more detail about this role, click Here.

This role is ideal for professionals passionate about policy, research, and social justice, who want to make a meaningful contribution to governance and public dialogue in South Africa and beyond.

If you have the skills, passion, and commitment to drive change—this is your opportunity to join one of Africa’s most influential legacy institutions.

 Discover more Job opportunities Here

item.content:encoded:
Are you a passionate early to mid-career leader committed to ending health disparities? Do you dream of joining a global network of change-makers equipped with the knowledge, skills, and network to transform health equity in your organization or community? If yes, this is one of the most powerful opportunities worldwide for emerging leaders like you.

What Is the Atlantic Fellows for Health Equity Fellowship?

The Atlantic Fellows for Health Equity is a fully funded, one-year leadership fellowship designed to develop global professionals committed to tackling inequities in health and well-being. It brings together diverse participants across sectors — from healthcare and academia to law, media, housing, business, research, and more — building leaders with a cross-sector mindset to drive impactful change.

The fellowship is hosted by the Milken Institute School of Public Health at the George Washington University and is part of the Atlantic Fellows global community, a network dedicated to advancing equity around the world.

What You’ll Do: Program Structure

Once selected, Fellows are expected to:

  • Attend in-person convenings throughout the year (total ~4 weeks)

  • Participate in a robust online curriculum (biweekly sessions + mentorship + team learning)

  • Engage in peer mentoring, coaching, and leadership development

  • Develop and advance a health equity project during the fellowship year

This hybrid learning experience includes both virtual and face-to-face components, designed to build real-world leadership and impact skills.

Benefits: Fully Funded & Empowering

One of the most compelling aspects of this fellowship is what it covers:

1. 100% of educational experiences and travel expenses are covered
2. Access to a global network of leaders in health equity
3. Leadership coaching, mentoring, and training
4. Collaborative peer community and lifelong connections
5. Opportunity to implement a meaningful project with expert support
6. Professional growth that strengthens your career and influence

Note: There is no stipend or salary provided, and Fellows are expected to remain employed while participating.

Who Should Apply? Eligibility & Qualifications

The fellowship seeks candidates who:

• Are early to mid-career professionals
• Are currently engaged in health-related work
• Hold or have the potential for leadership roles
• Are motivated to address health inequities globally
• Value diverse perspectives and collaborative work
• Are proficient in English

No specific degree or profession is required — the program welcomes leaders from across disciplines including public health, medicine, law, research, government, social enterprise, media, and more.

Apply here

Selection Criteria: What Makes You Stand Out

Candidates are evaluated based on:

  • Strength of Statement of Interest — Why you want this fellowship

  • Project Proposal Quality — Innovative, impactful health equity project

  • Leadership Experience & Commitment — Demonstrated through your work

  • Letters of Recommendation — Professional references that speak to your potential

  • Employer Support Form — Signed by a supervisor confirming your participation

Application Components Checklist

Before you apply, be ready with:

1. Personal background information
2. Short written responses about your leadership journey
3. Project proposal details and expected impact
4. Employer Support Form (signed)
5. Two letters of recommendation (one from supervisor)
6. Current CV or Resume
7. Recorded video responses (after written submission)

Pro tip: Prepare your written answers offline using the official worksheet available on the application page to ensure quality and accuracy.

Important 2026–2027 Deadlines & Timeline

You can apply now to the 2027 cohort, which follows the 2026 application cycle.

Application Timeline (2026–2027 Cycle):

Event Date
Applications Open February 18, 2026
Informational Webinar February 25, 2026
Application Deadline March 18, 2026
Applications Reviewed April – May 2026
Interviews Invited June 2026
Acceptance Notifications Late July 2026
Program Year January – November 2027 (approx.)

Joining the Atlantic Fellows for Health Equity is not just about gaining skills — it’s about becoming part of a global force shaping the future of health justice. Alumni continue to collaborate, influence policy, and lead major initiatives long after the fellowship year ends.
